moves.1. d4 c6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. e3 d6 4. Bd3 e5: e5 is a good move.  It immediately threatens e4, which causes problems for White.  And I reacted poorly.
moves.5. dxe5 dxe5 6. Nxe5: This is idiotic on my part.  Shortly after I hit the send button, I realized that I had hung the N to a simple Q check.
moves.6... Qa5+ 7. Nd2 Qxe5: Black is now much better.  Black has a material advantage and open diagonals for the Bs.
moves.8. Nf3: White gets the N to a better square and gains a tempo.
moves.8... Qc7 9. O-O Bd6 10. h3: Allowing the N to be pinned with Bg4 would be ugly.
moves.10... h6: I think h6 was unnecessary.  Ng5 is not much of a threat.  I think Black should 0-0 or develop with Be6.
moves.11. Bd2 Nbd7: It might be better to play Be6 before blocking it in with the N.
moves.12. Bc3: This was the best available square for the B.  The original diagonal is blocked with a pawn.
moves.12... O-O 13. Qe2 a6: I think a6 may also be unnecessary.  Black is now lagging behind in development.
moves.14. Rfd1 Re8 15. Qf1 Nc5: Moving the N from d7 allows a pawn weakness to be created.
moves.16. Bxf6 gxf6: Now Black's K is somewhat exposed.  With good play the material advantage should still decide, but Black now has to be more careful.
moves.17. a3: This was intended to slowly improve my position and prepare b4 if needed.
moves.17... b5 18. Nd4: This improves the position of my N.
moves.18... Nxd3 19. Qxd3 Be5: Black threatens to play c5 now and when the N moves, leave b2 exposed.
moves.20. c3 Rd8 21. Qe4: Adding a second attacker to c6 and threatening to win the pawn.
moves.21... Bb7: This move is tempting, but ignores the danger to Black's K.  With a material advantage, Black should just exchange with Bxd4.  That removes one of the attackers and makes it very difficult for Black to lose.
moves.22. Nf5: White is not worried about the possible discovered attack on the Q because there is a check in his back pocket.
moves.22... c5: c5 would normally be a good move, but here it leads to a checkmate.  I think Black simply underestimated the threat to the K.  It's important to have a sense of danger.
moves.23. Qg4+: Black resigns because all roads lead to checkmate.  Kh8 or Kh7 fail to the immediate Qg7#.  If Kf8, Black still plays Qg7+.  After Ke8 (forced, since e7 is covered by the N), Qg8#.  The last flight square, d7, is covered by White's R.
